fields.name: Insulate your water heater
fields.content:
Is this right for me?

Your hot water heater needs insulation if it has an R-value of less than 24. Don't know your hot water heater's R-value ... or even what an R-value is? Relax. Touch the outside of your water heater. If your heater is warm to the touch, you need extra insulation."Energy Savers: Insulate Your Water Heater Tank for Energy Savings." U.S. Department of Energy. 24 March 2009. 3 March 2010.

The rewards

Without proper insulation, your hot water heater is heating your basement in addition to your hot water. Adding a blanket will trap heat where it belongs and lower your hot water bill by up to 10%.

{% action_form %}

Get it done!

Step 1: Size your hot water heater

You'll need to know the gallon size of your hot water tank. Your manual has this information, but if you're like us, your manual is long gone.

No big. Most residential hot water heaters hold 30-50 gallons.Nunan, Jon. "Hot Water Needs" Service Magic. n.d. 20 Jan. 2010 Unless your house is unusually big, you can work with this number.

Step 2: Buy an insulation kit

Armed with the knowledge about your heater's size, head to your local hardware store. While shopping for water heater blankets, you'll come across a happy surprise: insulating blankets are downright cheap. Most sell for under $20. Since they'll save you a bundle on hot water costs, you'll easily recoup your investment in less than a year,Based on calculations from http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=products.pr_pie and keep saving money for years to come.

Okay, let's pick the right blanket and start saving money right away. Buy one that fits your water heater and has an R-value of 8 or more."Energy Savers: Insulate Your Water Heater Tank for Energy Savings." U.S. Department of Energy. 24 March 2009. 3 March 2010. Then head back home and get it installed.

Step 3: Install the insulation

Your time is now! If you have an electric hot water heater, you can easily install the insulation yourself. This video will give you the low-down, but all you need is scissors and a couple of free minutes.

Installing blankets on gas and oil powered heaters is a bit trickier. You want to make sure you keep the insulation away from both the bottom and top of the heater. We recommend having a qualified professional do it for you. Safety first!

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Keep your heater nice n' toasty while saving 10% on your water heating bill."Energy Savers: Insulate Your Water Heater Tank for Energy Savings." U.S. Department of Energy. 24 March 2009. 3 March 2010.

fields.name: Replace your outdated refrigerator
fields.content:
Is this action right for me?

Consider an upgrade if your current model is more than ten years old. If your refrigerator is old enough to worry about starting middle school, it's likely the biggest energy-guzzling appliance in your home."Energy Savers Tip: Appliances." Department of Energy. 22 Jan 2009. 30 March 2010.

The rewards

A new refrigerator will use 30-40% less energy than a 10-year-old unit."Statistic for a typical, new 18.5-cu.-ft. refrigerator with top-mount freezer (without a through-the-door ice dispenser). "Residential Sector: Efficient Refrigerators." Flex Your Power. n.d. 30 March 2010.

{% action_form %}

What should I know?

Buy Energy Star, be an energy star

Look for the blue Energy Star label when selecting your appliance. Energy Star refrigerators use 20% less energy than similar, non-certified models." This calculator will tell you how much energy your current fridge is wasting when compared to a new model. You can find an Energy Star model for almost any type of refrigerator, giving you access to all the latest features.

Get cash back

Many states, manufacturers and utilities offer tax credits and rebates on Energy Star certified appliances. That's like getting paid to save money on your electricity bill. To find incentives in your 'hood, check out this easy-to-use database from Energy Star.
fields.teaser: A new fridge will pay you dividends every month with energy savings.

fields.name: Set your water heater to 120°F
fields.content:
Is this action right for me?

A long time ago, in a secret meeting in a smoke-filled room, hot water bosses got together and decided to pre-set hot water tanks to 140°. If you haven't ever changed yours, it's likely that it's set too high.

The rewards

Hot water heaters set to 140° run the risk of scalding you. This is especially dangerous for children and senior citizens. A lower setting will also save you some real energy. By moving your hot water heater temperature from 140° to 120°, you can save around $200 over five years.Vandenbergh, Michael P. et al. "Individual Carbon Emissions: The Low-Hanging Fruit." UCLA Law Review 1701 (2008): 1746 {% action_form %}

What should I know?

You'll find it's pretty easy to locate the thermostat. Consult this chart to find the location of your thermostat. If you're fed up with reading, sit back, relax, and watch these two folks adjust their water heaters.

Gas Water Heaters:

Sometimes, heaters don't have clear markings on the dials. Turning the dial counterclockwise means you're turning the temperature down. If you start running out of hot water, you can always adjust the temperature back up by turning the dial clockwise.

Electric Water Heaters:

These usually have two thermostats that you'll need to adjust.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Save hundreds with a turn of a dial.

fields.name: Have a home energy audit and retrofit
fields.content:
Is this action right for me?

Nearly two-thirds of all single-family homes have inadequate or poor insulation.Levy, Jonathan I et al. "The public health benefits of insulation retrofits in existing housing in the United States." Environmental Health: A Global Access Science Source 2003, 2:4. Is your home among them? Poor insulation leads to waste, high energy bills and drafty, uncomfortable rooms. An energy auditor will recommend custom solutions to your home's problems that form the basis of a successful retrofit.

The rewards

The benefits of the audit/retrofit process are enormous for both your comfort, your wallet and our health.

  • After a retrofit, the average homeowner reduces her energy use by over 20%.http://www.mdhomeperformance.org/faqs.html#cost
  • If we retrofitted every home in America that needed it, the pollution reductions from the energy savings would prevent 6,500 asthma attacks every year, among other public health benefits.Levy, Jonathan I et al. "The public health benefits of insulation retrofits in existing housing in the United States." Environmental Health: A Global Access Science Source 2003, 2:4.
  • Because a retrofit lowers energy bills and improves comfort, it's also a great way to add value to your home. Data show that for every dollar saved in annual utility costs, homeowners can expect to add about $20 to the market value of their home. In other words, a homeowner that saves $300 on annual heating and cooling costs by adding insulation could add $6,000 to the market value of his home.Labor Day Home Improvement Projects That Pay28 Aug 2007

Judy, a homeowner in DC, thought her home was pretty efficient, but was blown away by the savings and improved comfort of her retrofitted home. Listen to her talk about her experience (via Weatherize DC).



{% action_form %}

Get it done!

Step 1: Find an energy auditor

Start your retrofit off right by having an energy audit. We recommend working with an energy auditor who is participating in the Home Performance with Energy Star program. Home Performance with Energy Star, a program of the Department of Energy, is now available in many states. Many states also offer incentives for both energy audits and the retrofit work. To find out if your state is participating, visit this page. If your state is not a participating member, you can still receive high-quality work from auditors who have standards like BPI and RESNET. Visit the BPI and RESNET page to find an auditor near you:

  • Find a BPI auditor
  • Find a RESNET auditor

Step 2: Organize your documents

Think of any concerns you may already have and collect your recent utility bills.

Step 3: Have the audit

Your auditor will perform several tests to measure your home's overall leakiness and pinpoint problems. At the end of the audit, your auditor will present you with a list of recommendations to solve your home's specific problems.

Step 4: Complete the retrofit work

The audit is just the first step! It's good to know where you stand, but you won't start saving energy until you implement the upgrades. With your auditor's recommendations in hand, you can work with a contractor to make the right improvements to your home. Your auditor may recommend a contractor, or you can use the BPI and RESNET links from step 1 to find a certified contractor.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Home energy auditors help you solve the unique problems in your home.

fields.name: Insulate your hot water pipes
fields.content:
Is this action right for me?

Leaving your pipes uninsulated is like strolling around in a tank top in a blizzard. Cover up those naked pipes with some insulation.

The rewards

If you insulate your pipes, they can deliver water that's 2–4ºF hotter."Insulate Hot Water Pipes for Energy Saving." Department of Energy. n.d. 20 May 2010. Insulated pipes are also much better protected against frost.

{% action_form %}

Get it done!

Step 1: Buy the insulation

You can get the insulation everywhere and it's cheap. Measure the diameter of your pipes before you head to the store, or ask a store clerk about the most common sizes. The diameter of your pipe should match the diameter of the insulation sleeve for a snug fit.

Step 2: Install the insulation

Installing the insulation is one of the easiest ways you can save energy: cut, wrap and tape. The most important sections of pipe are three feet or closer to your hot water heater."Insulate Hot Water Pipes for Energy Savings." Department of Energy. 24 Feb 2009. 26 May 2010. If you have a gas or oil-powered water heater, make sure to keep your insulation at least six inches away from the flue.Ibid.

Watch this video to see how simple it can be!

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Instead of heating the basement, keep energy in place with insulation.

fields.name: Install a chimney draft guard
fields.content:
Is this right for me?

A roaring fire keeps your home cozy, but unused fireplaces are a huge source of drafts. Drafts come charging down the flue, pulling warm air away from your hearth and letting cold air come right on in to your family room.

The rewards

Fireplaces account for 14% of total "air infiltration" in the typical home."Energy Savers Booklet: Tips on Saving Energy & Money at Home." Department of Energy. May 2009. 29 March 2010. Brrr! Stop drafts in their tracks by using a chimney draft guard whenever your fireplace is not in use.

{% action_form %}

Get it done!

Only you can prevent leaky fireplaces. Check out how easy draft guards are to install and use:

Step 1: Size your fireplace

It's important that the chimney draft guard fits snugly.

Step 2: Order your draft guard

Step 3: Install the draft guard

Keep the guard in place whenever you're not using your fireplace — unless you need to leave it open for Santa or other visitors unaccustomed to using doors. When the guard comes in contact with heat, it will deflate and fall out, so there's no risk of combustion.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: It looks like a balloon, but it's actually an incredibly effective stopper for your chimney.

fields.name: Use the cold wash cycle
fields.content:
Is this right for me?

If your washing machine could talk, it would probably say two things:

  • "Stop spilling mustard on your shirts!"
  • "Switch to the cold cycle!"

Take your washing machine's advice — switch to the cold wash cycle.

The rewards

When you wash your clothes in hot water, 90% of the energy is used to heat the water.Chua, Jasmin M. "Beat the Heat, Wash in Cold." Planet Green. 23 March 2008. 3 March 2010. By switching to the cold cycle, you save energy and money. Your clothes will be brighter and your wallet will be mightier!

{% action_form %}

What should I know?

Out damn spot

There are many laundry detergents available that are specifically formulated to work with cold water, including Tide Coldwash™ and Woolite Liquid Cold Water Wash™. As an added bonus, clothes last longer when they're washed in cold water.

Dirty little secret

The warm water in your washing machine does not disinfect your clothes. The water simply doesn't get hot enough to kill germs. Use bleach or another disinfectant to sanitize your clothes, and stop wasting money on the warm wash cycle.

http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Wellness/washing-machines-loaded-bacteria-dirty-clothes/story?id=10751420&page=1 {% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Every time you wash your clothes, you could be saving 90% on energy costs.

fields.name: Use a programmable thermostat
fields.content:
Is this right for me?

Heating and cooling are the biggest energy expenses in most homes, and programmable thermostats can significantly cut costs for virtually every home. If you have a manual thermostat, you can also save by going here.

The rewards

A programmable thermostat will likely save you hundreds of dollars every year while making your home effortlessly more comfortable. You can set it, forget it, and watch the savings add up.

{% action_form %}

What should I know?

Get With The Program

If you've been intimidated in the past by your programmable thermostat, don't despair. Having a better home is easier than you think, and it's all just a few clicks away. Here's an example of how to program a thermostat.

Find Your Model

If you need more specific information, you can find step-by-step instructions for your model by selecting your thermostat manufacturer:

  • Honeywell
  • Lux
  • Hunter
  • White-Rodgers

Make Your Savings Plan

The ideal time to set back your thermostat is when your home is empty or when you're asleep. Think about when you typically go to bed, leave in the morning and come home at night. Set your thermostat to lower your heat or air conditioning while you're asleep or at work, and turn back up by the time you wake up or get home. During the winter, rolling back your thermostat from 72° to 60° for eight hours a day will save you around 12% on your heating bill.Department of Energy, Energy Savers, Thermostats and Control Systems You can achieve similar savings in the summer by raising your thermostat.

  • Download the setback activity sheet

Common Thermostat Myths

"If I set my thermostat to 80°, my house will get hotter, faster."

Your heating and cooling system only has two modes: on and off. The rate at which it heats or cools your home is unaffected by the temperature setting. By setting your thermostat higher, you’re just ensuring that your heater will be on for longer than you need and your house will be hotter or colder than you want. Set your thermostat to the temperature you actually want and let it be.

"Turning my thermostat down doesn’t really save energy! My HVAC system will just have to work harder when I get back."

This is a common myth, but it's false. Using your thermostat to turn your heat or air conditioner down will save energy. Period.

Consider the following example: Let’s say you want your home to be 72° degrees in the winter. You leave your house at 8am and return at 6pm. If you have a programmable thermostat set to turn the heat off, you will use absolutely no energy during that 10-hour period. If you leave your thermostat at 72°, your heat will continually switch on and off, heating an empty house for 10 hours.
When your programmable thermostat switches back on to heat your house, it will stay on for slightly longer than the thermostat that has been left alone. However, the slight increase in energy use during this time period pales in comparison to the energy saved during that 10-hour period.

"My pipes will freeze!"

If your pipes are not well-insulated inside your home, and the outside air temperature is below 20°, you should consider keeping your thermostat above 55°.Severe Weather Readiness Weather.com. n.d. 7 Apr 2010 This setback still allows room for significant savings. However, a much more effective way to prevent your pipes from freezing and bursting is to insulate exposed pipes.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Want a comfortable home with no hassle? Say hello to your thermostat.

fields.name: Dial down your thermostat
fields.content:
Is this right for me?

What's the difference between a room that's 72° and a room that's 74°?

Some serious energy savings! You probably won't be able to feel the difference, but you'll definitely be able to see the savings on your energy bill.

The rewards

A savvy homeowner who changes her thermostat is saving as much as $125 every year &mdash just by going down or up two degrees.Vandenbergh, Michael P. et al. "Individual Carbon Emissions: The Low-Hanging Fruit." UCLA Law Review 1701 (2008): 1744 Would you like to be $125 richer? Raise your thermostat two degrees in the summer and lower it two degrees in the winter!

{% action_form %}

Get it done!

Step 1: Experiment to find a comfortable setting

While two degrees will save you real cash, you'll save even more if your setback is a bit higher or lower. Find a setting that's comfortable for you and start saving right now.

Step 2: Enact your reduced settings

Just thinking about it doesn't save energy. Do some stretches, warm up your fingers, and go over to your thermostat. With a few pushes of a button, you too can be an energy-saving star.

{% action_form %}

fields.name: Replace five light bulbs with CFLs
fields.content:
Is this right for me?

In 1879, Thomas Edison demonstrated his light bulb to awestruck crowds. Americans were still getting used to indoor plumbing, so electric lights were kinda a big deal. Nowadays, many homes are still using lighting technology that's virtually unchanged since Thomas Edison's day. If you haven't switched out your incandescent light bulbs, you're partying like a Victorian. Invest in some compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFLs) today and join the 21st century.

The rewards

You may have heard it all before, but let's just take a moment to review how awesome CFLs are:

  • CFLs are four times more efficient than outdated incandescent light bulbs.http://www.greenamerica.org/pubs/realgreen/articles/cfls.cfm
  • The average home has 45 light bulbs. Switching all of these bulbs will save you over $1,300 over the bulbs' lifetimes.Dakss, Brian. "'Green' Light Bulb Buying Guide." CBS News. 22 June 2007. 5 March 2010.ENERGY STAR, "Compact Fluorescent Light Bulbs for Consumers." n.d. 5 March 2010.
  • If every household in the United States installed just one CFL, we would prevent greenhouse gas emissions equivalent to those of more than 800,000 cars annually"Frequently Asked Questions: Information on Compact Fluorescent Light Bulbs (CFLs) and Mercury." Energy Star. July 2008..
  • CFLs last 10 times longer, which means fewer trips to the hardware store and fewer arguments over why there's still a blown-out bulb in the kitchen.
{% action_form %}

Get it done!

Buy the bulbs

Almost every hardware store now carries CFLs, including big retailers like Target and Home Depot.

The package will tell you what wattage to buy based on the light you're replacing. A 60 Watt incandescent bulb, for example, can be replaced by a 13-15 Watt CFL bulb. http://energystar.custhelp.com/cgi-bin/energystar.cfg/php/enduser/std_adp.php?p_faqid=2563

Act now

It's hard to know when it's time to trade in your car for a newer model. Not so with incandescent light bulbs. Every day you wait, you're wasting energy that you could easily be saving. Replace those bulbs today.

FAQs

What's the deal with mercury in CFLs?

The rumors are true: CFLs contain a small amount of mercury. Really small — many CFLs now contain less than 1 milligram of mercury.Ibid. To put that in perspective, the average aspirin tablet weighs 325 milligrams. Old thermometers, on the other hand, contain around 500 milligrams of mercuryIbid.

Because they do contain a small amount of mercury, CFLs should be recycled at the end of their lives. Visit Earth911 to find a recycling center near you.

No mercury is released when the bulbs are intact. If you do break a bulb, it's okay. Open a window and leave the room for 15 minutes. When you come back, use tape to pick up any shards of glass, and vacuum the area thoroughly. For more information about CFL disposal, visit the Energy Star information page.

More CFLs = less mercury

Say what? It's true. The adoption of CFLs will actually reduce the amount of mercury released into our environment. Since CFLs are so much more efficient, they require much less energy than incandescent bulbs to produce the same amount of light. That means we can significantly reduce our demand for coal, the most common source of electricity in the U.S. Burning coal is a dirty business. It releases all sorts of nasty chemicals, including a lot of mercury. When you compare their life cycle impacts, CFLs leave incadescents behind in a cloud of soot.

Ibid. {% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFLs) are awesome in so many ways.

fields.name: Insulate your windows
fields.content:
Leaky windows are the worst. Heat loss from your windows can account for 10-25% of your winter heating bill."Energy Saver Tips: Windows." Energy Savers. Department of Energy. 22 Jan 2009. 25 Jan 2010. Recently, we read about a guy who was so frustrated by his leaky windows that he moved to a windowless, underground lair.

Okay ... by "guy" we mean "supervillain." And by "read" we mean "saw it on a cartoon." Same thing, right?

The point is that leaky windows can drive you bonkers. You can literally feel money leaving your house through leaks. And the uncomfortable drafts seem like they belong in Little House on the Prairie, not your modern home.

Fortunately, you don't have to go through the hassle and expense of building an underground lair to escape drafts. If you have a free hour, you can insulate your windows.

{% action_form %}

Step One: Buy an insulation kit

Window insulation kits contain a special plastic sheet and double-sided tape. The sheet traps air between the sheet and glass, creating an insulating barrier. Kits — like those from 3M and Ace — are easy to install and generally cost less than $4 per window.

Step 2: Put it on up

With just some scissors and a few minutes, you can stop uncomfortable drafts. This guy successfully insulates his windows with his eyes covered:

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Stop leaks in their tracks with a window insulation kit.

fields.name: Set your computer to sleep automatically
fields.content:
Is this right for me?

Did you know that the typical computer uses most of its energy when no one is sitting in front of it?Energy Center of Wisconsin. "Electricity Savings Opportunities for Home Electronics and Other Plug-In Devices in Minnesota Homes." May 2010, p. 21 Configure your power management settings to reduce this use.

The rewards

Without proper sleep setting enabled, each computer is costing you an additional $25-$75 every year."Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)." ENERGY STAR. n.d. 27 Jan 2010. Your computer works hard sending your email, reading blogs and enabling your online shopping addiction. Give it a rest!

{% action_form %}

Get it done

Make a plan

It's easy to customize your power management preferences. Set your computer to enter sleep mode after 15 minutes or less of inactivity. Have the monitor also turn off after 15 minutes or less of inactivity.

Change your settings

In Windows XP:

Start -> Control Panel -> Power Options

In Windows Vista & Windows 7:

Start -> Control Panel -> Hardware and Sound -> Change Power-Saving Settings

In Mac OS X:

System Preferences -> Energy Saver


Common myths

"A blank screen means my computer is asleep"

Your monitor may be asleep, but your computer processor can still be on. When the processor is on, it's still using almost as much energy as it is when you're using it. The only way to reduce this energy use is to turn the computer off or set it to sleep/hibernate.

"Screensavers save energy"

A computer uses just as much energy when displaying a screen saver as when it's on.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Imagine a wonderful world where you could save money by sleeping.
